header.title: Order of Nine Angles - Collection of Books: The Black Book Of Satan I, II, & III
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Satanism, Black Magick

central_thesis: The Order of Nine Angles (ONA) presents a practical and experiential philosophy of life aiming for individual self-divinity and understanding through the engagement with magickal forces. This is achieved via a structured 'seven-fold sinister way' of self-development, involving a progressive series of Grade Rituals and both internal and external Black Magick, often through transgressive and dangerous practices, to open nexions to acausal energies and ultimately manifest the 'Dark Gods' on Earth.

structure_content.chapter_title: Order of Nine Angles 'Books' Database Preface
structure_content.summary: This preface introduces the collection as a re-presentation of the ONA 'Books' database, originally found on 'www.MurderDeathKill.net'. It notes that 'Naos' is a separate file and lists other ONA databases (Manuscripts, Chants, Interviews, Tales & Poetry, The Deofel Quintet). It specifies the compilation date (May 2004), the number of books (4, including Naos), and page count (222), while explicitly stating the summary is not O.N.A.-authorized. The compilers are listed as Caput Mortuum, Ayin Quadma'ah Movement.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Black Book Of Satan Part One: Contents & The XXI Satanic Points
structure_content.summary: Part One outlines the core philosophical tenets of the ONA through 'The XXI Satanic Points', emphasizing strength, victory, conquest, self-mastery, and rejection of weakness and conventional morality. It introduces foundational concepts of ONA Satanism, defining it as a practical philosophy focused on self-realization through external (sorcery) and internal (Adeptship quest) magick. It details the establishment and preparation of an ONA Temple (indoor/outdoor, altar, implements, Baphomet's role) and the general principles of ceremonial rituals, stressing drama, emotion, and controlled frenzy for energy generation and direction.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Black Book Of Satan Part One: Ceremonial Rituals
structure_content.summary: This section provides detailed scripts and instructions for various ONA ceremonial rituals. These include 'The Black Mass' (a threefold rite of inversion, liberation, and magickal energy generation, with specific participants and preparations), 'The Ceremony of Birth' (dedicating a newborn to the ONA clan), 'The Death Rite' (a curse ritual using a wax effigy and sexual magick), 'The Pledging' (a traditional Satanic wedding ceremony involving oaths and blood-marking), 'The Rite of Initiation' (for new members, including tests of fidelity, knowledge, and courage, and involving sexual acts and oath-taking), 'Consecration of The Temple' (dedicating a space to the 'powers of Darkness' using an Elixir and sealing rites), and 'The Dying Time' (a funeral pyre ritual for deceased members). It also details the training path for Initiates through 'Satanic Orders' and the Grade Rituals of the seven-fold way, emphasizing the difficult and dangerous nature of this experiential path. 'Sinister Chant' explains methods of vocal magick (vibration, chanting, Esoteric Chant) and provides examples (Diabolus, Sanctus Satanas, Invokation to Baphomet).

structure_content.chapter_title: The Black Book Of Satan Part Two: The Septenary System
structure_content.summary: Part Two, authored by Christos Beest, primarily focuses on the Septenary System, presenting 21 esoteric entities or 'spheres' (e.g., NAOS, AOSOTH, ATZAZOTH, NYTHRA, SHUGARA, BINAN ATH) each accompanied by a sigil and a short, evocative poem or descriptive verse. These entities represent key aspects or 'angles' within the ONA's cosmology, hinting at their properties and connections within the Tree of Wyrd. This section serves as a symbolic reference for understanding the subtle energies and pathways central to ONA magick and gnosis.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Black Book Of Satan Part Three: Contents & The Sinister Calling
structure_content.summary: Part Three, also by Christos Beest, outlines a further set of advanced and specialized rituals and appendices. 'The Sinister Calling' describes a ceremonial ritual to either return 'Dark Gods' to Earth or channel chaotic acausal energies towards a specific goal, emphasizing the requirement of willing sacrifice and stringent preparations (seven-day 'Black Fast', sexual union for nexion opening). It specifies temple setup, participant roles (Master, Mistress, Priestess, Priest, Opfer, Guardian), and the ritual sequence involving chants, dance, and the S.Knife for elixir collection.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Black Book Of Satan Part Three: Specialized Masses & Ceremonies
structure_content.summary: This section details several specialized rituals. 'The Black Mass of Life (The Promethean Office I)' includes chants and hymns for daily or ad libitum performance. 'The Mass of Heresy' is described as an illegal and dangerous ritual aiming to challenge historical beliefs (specifically promoting National Socialist ideology and denying the Holocaust), provoke dissent, and encourage dark forces. 'The Black Mass - Gay Version' provides guidelines for gay initiates, adapting roles and sexual practices to same-sex participants while maintaining core ritual structures. 'Synestry: A Sinister Ceremony' is a Sapphic temple ritual with a focus on female roles (Amatrix, Priestess, Defensatrix) and involving specific sexual acts to generate and direct magickal energy. 'The Rite of the Nine Angles' is a highly dangerous ritual, existing in Natural, Chthonic, and Solo forms, designed to open a 'Star Gate' and bring 'Dark Gods' to the causal universe, often involving sexual union and a crystal tetrahedron.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Black Book Of Satan Part Three: The Ceremony of Recalling & Appendices
structure_content.summary: This chapter describes 'The Ceremony of Recalling With Sacrificial Conclusion', detailing a complex and extreme ritual involving a chosen 'Opfer' (Priest) who is prepared for sacrifice over a year, culminating in ritual sexual acts and physical sacrifice to generate a 'Red Elixir' for consecration. Appendices include 'The Nine Angles - Esoteric Meanings', which explains the concept of the 'nine angles' in relation to the Tree of Wyrd, causal/acausal tetrahedrons, and the Star Game as a means to achieve 'acausal thinking'. 'The Secrets of the Nine Angles' provides diagrams illustrating the relationship between the nine angles, the inverted pentagram, and specific chants for generating and directing magickal energy from various spheres. 'Chants' provides musical notations and texts for various ONA chants.

key_concepts.definition: A practical philosophy of life centered on achieving self-divinity and understanding through the engagement with magickal forces. It involves embracing one's dark nature and following a structured seven-fold path to Adeptship, prioritizing experiential knowledge and defying conventional morality.

External magick is sorcery, aimed at changing external events, circumstances, or individuals. Internal magick is the transformation of the magician's consciousness, forming the quest for higher magickal attainment (Adeptship).

A system used in traditional Satanism (also known as the Hebdomadry) involving seven spheres or paths, analogous to other esoteric systems, used for magickal understanding and self-development. The Tree of Wyrd is a representation of this.

The difficult and dangerous path of self-development within the ONA, comprising a series of Grade Rituals (e.g., Initiation, External Adept, Internal Adept) designed to impart magickal understanding and self-insight, fostering the 'Satanist spirit' and culminating in Adeptship.

Entities or chaotic energies from acausal dimensions, which can be invoked and potentially brought into causal manifestation through specific ONA rituals, such as The Sinister Calling and The Rite of the Nine Angles.

Regarded by ONA Satanists as a 'violent goddess', the archetype of the Mistress of Earth and the Bride of Lucifer. She is depicted as a beautiful, naked woman holding a severed head and a burning torch, representing a core aspect of their tradition.
Described as a primal form, a dark nebulous chaos, or a rend in the fabric of star-strewn space, often visualized in connection with the opening of a Star Gate or as a 'dragon-like entity'.
A gate or link between the causal (ordinary reality) and acausal (darker, chaotic dimensions) realms. ONA rituals aim to open these nexions to channel or manifest acausal energies/entities.

A large quartz crystal, often tetrahedron-shaped, that is central to many ONA rituals. It serves as a tool for concentrating and directing magickal energy, opening nexions/Star Gates, and facilitating visualization.

A ceremonial ritual with a threefold purpose: a positive inversion of the Nazarene mass, a means of personal liberation from dogma (blasphemy), and a magickal rite that generates and directs sinister energy.

A consecrated liquid often prepared for ONA rituals. The 'Red Elixir' for the Sacrificial Conclusion ritual specifically involves the Master's semen and Priestess's blood, mixed with other ingredients.

Meaning 'The Chosen One' or 'Sacrifice', this term refers to the individual selected for ritualistic sacrifice in certain advanced ONA ceremonies, particularly the 'Ceremony of Recalling With Sacrificial Conclusion'.

A series of tasks and undertakings that form the structured training path of the ONA, designed to achieve magickal understanding and self-insight. These rituals incrementally advance an Initiate along the seven-fold sinister way towards Adeptship and beyond.

A new form of understanding that arises from playing the Star Game and relating abstract symbols to conventional representations, developing the capacity to view collocations abstractly and extending consciousness into new realms, moving beyond linear thought.

practical_system.description: The ONA's system is a practical, experiential, and hierarchical path to self-divinity and adeptship through internal and external Black Magick. It integrates a unique cosmology (Septenary System, Tree of Wyrd, causal/acausal nexions, Dark Gods) with a progressive series of 'Grade Rituals' (the seven-fold sinister way). Practitioners are encouraged to form temples, undertake challenging and often dangerous experiences, and perform elaborate ceremonies designed to generate and direct magickal energy, open portals to acausal dimensions, and facilitate the manifestation of 'Dark Gods'. The system emphasizes direct experience over theoretical study, personal transformation, and a defiant rejection of conventional morality.
tools: Altar (stone or wood, covered with black/red cloth, woven sigils like inverted pentagram/septagon)
Candles (black, other colors, often in lanterns)
Quartz sphere, crystal, or tetrahedron (central to many rites for energy direction/nexion opening)
Ceremonial robes (black, crimson, purple, white, viridian, often hooded)
Graveyard earth (collected on new moon night)
Incense (hazel, yew, black poplar, Mars, Jupiter, petriochor)
Consecrated cakes (made from honey, spring water, sea salt, wheat flour, eggs, animal fat, sometimes marijuana)
Small card with ritual texts (e.g., 'Satanic Our Father', 'Sinister Creed')
Image/sculpture of Baphomet (or Atu III, IV, XX of Sinister Tarot)
Copy of 'Mein Kampf' and photograph of 'The Leader' (optional for Mass of Heresy)
rituals: The Black Mass (various versions including Gay and traditional with sexual rites)
The Death Rite (including wax effigy curse)
The Rite of Initiation (with sexual acts and oath-taking)
Consecration of The Temple (with Elixir and Rite of Sealing)
The Dying Time (funeral pyre for deceased members)
The Ceremony of Recalling (with symbolic or literal sacrificial conclusion)
The Sinister Calling (invoking Dark Gods, with sacrificial aspects)
The Mass of Heresy (incorporating National Socialist ideology)
Synestry: A Sinister Ceremony (Sapphic temple ritual)
The Rite of the Nine Angles (Natural, Chthonic, and Solo forms to open Star Gates)

relevant_quotes.text: Satanism is fundamentally a way of living - a practical philosophy of life. The essence of this way is the belief that we can all, as individuals, achieve far more with our lives than we realize. Most people waste the opportunities that life can, by magick, be made to bring.

The whole text of the traditional Black Book is included in the present work, together with several additional chapters (e.g. Self-Initiation; Organizing and Running a Temple). These additions make this present work a concise practical handbook for those seriously interested in the Black Arts.

To successful, a ceremonial ritual must be both dramatic and emotional. That is, the right atmosphere has to be created and maintained. The object is to involve the emotions of the congregation, and all the many ritualized elements (e.g. the robes and the candles) are a means to aid this.

To open a Star Gate and return the Dark Gods to our causal universe a crystal tetrahedron made of quartz is required. This should be as large as possible - and made from a natural shape by a skilled operator.

The Black Mass has been greatly misunderstood. It is not simply an inversion of Nazarene symbolism and words - when a Nazarene mass is celebrated (...) certain energies or vibrations compatible with the Nazarene ethos may or may not be generated (...) What a genuine Black Mass does is 'tune into' those energies and then alter them in a sinister way.

The aim of this Mass is to a) challenge accepted beliefs about recent history; b) provoke dissent and encourage Promethean challenge - particularly within the psyche of the individual; c) encourage dark forces. It should be noted that performance of this Mass is illegal in many Western countries - and acceptance of its tenets renders individuals liable to persecution.

The name nine angles is, in one fundamental sense, selfdescriptive': the Tree of Wyrd possesses nine causal angles and nine acausal angles in the causal geometric sense, and these can be represented as formed by the corners or angles of a causal and acausal tetrahedron, one a reflexion of the other, the base lying in the plane of the middle sphere (the sun).

Thus it can be seen that the training of Initiates in genuine Satanic Orders is both comprehensive and difficult, for Satanic Orders are not religious institutions committed to indoctrinating their members, just as they are not groups for the discussion and study of magickal and Occult topics. They are places where real sinister magick is undertaken - this real magick is difficult and may at times be dangerous.

critical_analysis.relevance: This collection is exceptionally relevant for understanding the core doctrines, practical applications, and controversial nature of the Order of Nine Angles (ONA). It serves as a foundational text for practitioners of ONA-style Satanism and provides invaluable primary source material for academic study of extreme right-wing and neo-Nazi currents within modern occultism. The detailed ritual instructions, philosophical tenets, and explicit references to human sacrifice (both symbolic and literal versions), alongside the incorporation of National Socialist ideology in rituals like 'The Mass of Heresy', highlight the unique and transgressive character of the ONA's system. Its emphasis on experiential learning, the 'seven-fold sinister way', and the creation of nexions to 'Dark Gods' positions it as a significant, albeit highly contentious, work in the field of Western Esotericism and Black Magick.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of individuals committed to practicing the specific form of Satanism and Black Magick advocated by the Order of Nine Angles. This includes aspiring initiates, members undergoing Grade Rituals, and Master/Mistress figures responsible for leading temples. The text explicitly states it is not for 'non-Initiates' or those without a serious, operative interest in the 'Black Arts'. Due to its detailed exposition of ONA philosophy and practices, including extreme elements, it also serves as a crucial resource for academic researchers, counter-terrorism analysts, and scholars of new religious movements interested in the ONA's ideology, structure, and operative magic.
